prompt:
You are provided with a list of characters, evidences and testimonies.
Characters:
Character 0
Name: Eddie Fender
Description: A student working part-time at the offices of Edgeworth and Co. Studying to be an attorney.
Character 1
Name: Samson Tangaroa
Description: My client, and a man said to be the greatest confectioner of his generation.
Character 2
Name: Artie Frost
Description: The murder victim. Found dead inside Samson Tangaroa's chocolate work.
Character 3
Name: Judy Bound
Description: Assistant to Samson Tangaroa. She's fond of the work of sculptor Paul Halique.
Character 4
Name: Tyrell Badd
Description: The detective assigned to this case. A man of few words.
Character 5
Name: Carmelo Gusto
Description: A candy-crafting confectioner who's taking part in the contest.
Character 6
Name: Delicia Scone
Description: A confectioner who will do whatever it takes to achieve her goals.
Character 7
Name: Manfred von Karma
Description: The prosecutor in charge of this case. It is said that he has never lost a trial in these past 25 years.
Character 8
Name: Laurice Deauxnim
Description: Pseudonym of Larry Butz, my friend since childhood. He fancies himself as something of an artist.
Character 9
Name: Dick Gumshoe
Description: Homicide detective from the local precinct who's always first on the scene at any murder investigation.
Character 10
Name: Kay Faraday
Description: A self-styled Great Thief and so-called "second Yatagarasu" who's always looking to bag the greatest treasure of all -- the truth.
Character 11
Name: Verity Gavèlle
Description: A district court judge and member of the Committee for Prosecutorial Excellence, who also acts as its mouthpiece.
Character 12
Name: Eustace Winner
Description: The greatest prosecutor ever to prosecute... according to himself, anyway. In actual fact, his relationship with logic is tenuous at best.
Evidences:
Evidence 0
Name: Attorney's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. Polishing it every day has become just another part of my daily routine.
Evidence 1
Name: Seal
Description: A seal that was found near the body when it was discovered. What could the design signify?
Evidence 2
Name: Crime Scene Notes
Description: Notes about the crime scene. The police have taken custody of the body. [info] The victim's body found in Samson Tangaroa's room, inside a chocolate treasure chest. The cause of death appears to have been blood loss following blunt force trauma. [caption] The victim's body is curled inside a chest crushed by a ship post. The body is half covered by a blue sheet. There is a silver coin next to the body.
Evidence 3
Name: Mr. Tangaroa's Teapot
Description: A Paul Halique piece with Tangaroa's fingerprints on it.
Evidence 4
Name: Contest Rules
Description: A piece of paper listing the rules for the contest.
Evidence 5
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Someone left finger marks on the chocolate frame, but didn't leave any prints.
Evidence 6
Name: Mansion Key
Description: The one and only key that unlocks every door in the mansion. Tangaroa was in possession of it the entire time.
Evidence 7
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: Salt lamp found in Scone's room. Stained with the victim's blood.
Evidence 8
Name: Fake Confections
Description: Ms. Scone's so-called creations were all fake plastic models, covered in a thick layer of whipped cream.
Evidence 9
Name: Chocolates
Description: Tangaroa's favorite, handmade by Bound. Rather misshapened, and incredibly sweet.
Evidence 10
Name: Instant Camera
Description: Takes photos that develop instantly. A new film cartridge has twenty exposures, but there are only three remaining.
Evidence 11
Name: Mr. Frost's Room
Description: A photo of Frost's sculptures, taken by Judy Bound. Two photos, one from Bound and one from Detective Badd.
Evidence 12
Name: Ms. Scone's Statement
Description: Frost's sculptures were "scrumptious", except for the lyre, which was salty.
Evidence 13
Name: Semifinal Entries
Description: Frost's and Gusto's creations had different designs, but tasted the same.
Evidence 14
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 15
Name: Victim's Blood
Description: Frost's blood was found in the fountain, but not at the scene of the crime.
Evidence 16
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 17
Name: Prosecutor's Badge
Description: Proof of my profession. However, I prefer to keep it in my pocket.
Evidence 18
Name: IS-7 Incident Case File
Description: Documents providing an overview of the IS-7 Incident. Documents received from Fender, including his comments in red.
Evidence 19
Name: Gallery Pamphlet
Description: A pamphlet received upon entry to the gallery.
Evidence 20
Name: Winter Wing Photo
Description: Statues matching those made by the victim eighteen years ago.
Evidence 21
Name: Pisces Statue Sketch
Description: A sketch by Larry depicting the Pisces statue exactly as he saw it.
Evidence 22
Name: Used Blowtorch
Description: There are signs it was used just before the police arrived. Possibly to heat something?
Evidence 23
Name: Luminous Cloth
Description: Cloth that glows when connected to a full-spectrum light-emitting device. [caption] Looks like a blue sheet. Delicia Scone's property. One of these was lost eighteen years ago. Given to Bound by Scone. Lost eighteen years ago, only to be rediscovered floating in the fountain.
Evidence 24
Name: Poison Gas Ingredients
Description: The gas was produced when bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion were mixed together.
Evidence 25
Name: Ultimate Cookbook
Description: A book containing formulas for creating a cure for taste disorders and other chemical and pharmaceutical items.
Evidence 26
Name: Frame Finger Marks
Description: Finger marks left by someone in Tangaroa's room. No accompanying prints.
Evidence 27
Name: Salt Lamp
Description: A photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident. It's a salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.
Evidence 28
Name: Family Photo
Description: A photo of Frost, Gusto, and their sons. Gusto's son visited his father daily up through the semifinal.
Evidence 29
Name: Teapot
Description: Designed by Paul Halique. One of Judy Bound's prize possessions.
Evidence 30
Name: Ceramic Fragment
Description: Found in a puddle of tea. The design looks familiar.
Evidence 31
Name: Lift Cart
Description: Used by Frost to transport ice eighteen years ago. The top of the platform is wet.
Evidence 32
Name: Larry's Sketches
Description: Sketches depicting exactly what Larry saw.
Evidence 33
Name: Gemini Case Analysis Results
Description: Results of the analysis conducted on the melted contents of the Gemini case.
Evidence 34
Name: Chocolates
Description: Handmade by Bound. Slightly melted after being kept in her pocket.
Evidence 35
Name: Statute of Limitations
Description: A book explaining the statutes of limitations of various crimes.

Testimonies:
Testimony 0
Testimony: If the body had been found in a locked room... Master would've been the prime suspect.
Person: Badd
Testimony 1
Testimony: That's why Master made sure to leave the door to his own room unlocked...
Person: Badd
Testimony 2
Testimony: And to ensure that the body would be seen... Master broke the lid on the treasure chest.
Person: Badd
Testimony 3
Testimony: After the judging... everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room...
Person: Badd
Testimony 4
Testimony: That would have created the impression... that the murder had occurred... while he was away.
Person: Badd

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Alright, so I need to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me start by going through the evidence and testimonies provided.

First, I'll look at the testimonies given by Badd. Testimony 0 says that if the body had been found in a locked room, Master would've been the prime suspect. Testimony 1 mentions that Master made sure to leave the door to his own room unlocked. Testimony 2 states that Master broke the lid on the treasure chest to ensure the body would be seen. Testimony 3 says that after the judging, everyone was scheduled to meet in Master's room. Testimony 4 explains that this setup would create the impression that the murder had occurred while Master was away.

Now, looking at the evidence, I see that Evidence 6 is a Salt Lamp stained with the victim's blood. This is significant because it suggests that the lamp was used as a murder weapon. Additionally, Evidence 27 is a photograph of the murder weapon from the IS-7 Incident, which is the same salt lamp stained with Frost's blood.

Badd's testimonies suggest that Master (Samson Tangaroa) was setting up the crime scene to frame someone else by making it look like the murder happened while he was away. However, the evidence of the salt lamp being stained with the victim's blood points directly to its use as a murder weapon. If Master had left the room unlocked and ensured the body was visible, it would imply he was present and involved, contradicting the idea that he was away.

Moreover, the salt lamp being a key piece of evidence ties directly to the method of murder, which Badd's testimonies don't account for. If Master was indeed setting up an alibi, the presence of the salt lamp as the murder weapon complicates that narrative, suggesting Master's direct involvement in the killing.

So, the contradiction lies between the testimonies that suggest Master was setting up an alibi and the evidence of the salt lamp as the murder weapon, indicating Master's direct role in the crime.
</think>

Testimonies:

Testimony: In order to pin the crime on Delicia, Master used the rock salt lamp to kill the victim.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 1

Person: von Karma
Testimony 2
Testimony: If he had left the murder weapon at the crime scene, Master would have been the one suspected.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 3
Testimony: He couldn't move the body, but it was easy to move the murder weapon.
Person: von Karma
Testimony 4
Testimony: Ergo, there would be no evidence pointing to a specific culprit at the crime scene.
Person: von Karma

Which evidence and testimony contradict each other? You must only answer one pair. You may output an explanation, but your answer must end with a JSON format like so: {"evidence": 2, "testimony": 3}. The answer JSON should strictly be the last line, followed by nothing else.
cot:
Okay, so I'm trying to figure out which evidence and testimony contradict each other in this case. Let me go through everything step by step.

First, I'll look at the characters involved. The main suspect seems to be Delicia Scone, and the prosecutor is Manfred von Karma. The victim is Artie Frost, who was found dead inside a chocolate treasure chest in Samson Tangaroa's room. The cause of death was blunt force trauma leading to blood loss.

Looking at the evidence, Evidence 7 is a salt lamp found in Delicia Scone's room, stained with the victim's blood. The prosecution's theory, as per von Karma's testimonies, is that Tangaroa killed Frost using the salt lamp and then moved the weapon to Scone's room to frame her. So, von Karma is suggesting that Tangaroa planted the lamp to make it look like Scone did it.

Now, let's examine the testimonies. Von Karma testifies that Tangaroa used the salt lamp to kill Frost and then moved it to Scone's room. He also mentions that Tangaroa couldn't move the body, so he moved the weapon instead, leaving no direct evidence at the crime scene.

But wait, looking back at the evidence, specifically Evidence 7, the salt lamp was found in Scone's room with Frost's blood on it. If von Karma is saying that Tangaroa moved the lamp to Scone's room, that would mean the lamp was at the crime scene originally. However, the crime scene notes (Evidence 2) mention that the victim's body was found inside a chocolate treasure chest, and there's a silver coin next to the body. There's no mention of a salt lamp at the crime scene.

This creates a contradiction because if the salt lamp was the murder weapon, it should have been at the crime scene. Instead, it was found in Scone's room. This suggests that the lamp was indeed planted there, which aligns with von Karma's testimony. But wait, the contradiction arises because the crime scene notes don't mention the lamp, which is crucial if it was the murder weapon. If the lamp wasn't at the crime scene, how can it be the murder weapon? This discrepancy suggests that the lamp might not have been used in the crime, contradicting von Karma's claim.

So, the contradiction is between the evidence that the salt lamp was found in Scone's room with the victim's blood and the testimony that Tangaroa used it as the murder weapon and moved it. If the lamp wasn't at the crime scene, it can't be the murder weapon, which undermines von Karma's case.
</think>

Person: Debeste

Person: Debeste
Testimony 2

Testimony: The paint, along with being the first witness! ...That pretty much proves he's the culprit!

cot:
Okay, let's tackle this problem step by step. I'm presented with a list of characters, evidences, and testimonies. My task is to identify which evidence and testimony contradict each other. 

First, I need to understand what each evidence and testimony says. 

Looking at the testimonies, Testimony 0 to 3 are from a character named Debeste. The key points are:
- The artist (Larry Deauxnim) was the first to discover the victim, making him the best suspect.
- The poison gas was caused by Normallium, a chemical found in paint.
- Larry was carrying paint near the victim, giving him the best chance to commit the crime.
- The combination of carrying paint and being the first witness proves he's the culprit.

Now, looking at the evidences, I need to find one that contradicts any of these points.

Evidence 24 describes the poison gas ingredients: it was produced by mixing bright red Ubiquium and pure white Asphyxion. This directly contradicts Testimony 1, which claims the poison gas was caused by Normallium found in paint. Since the evidence specifies the exact chemicals involved, it refutes the testimony's assertion about Normallium being the cause.

Therefore, the contradiction lies between Evidence 24 and Testimony 1.
</think>
